page.lettertext:
fol.258r
July
[To]
my L. Trea
s
May it please your good L. Up
o
the sight of your l
re
of
e 20 of this
moneth, w
ch
was delivered me to day, I should thinke it very long, till
your L. receaved mine answear unto it, but
at I hope
e sundrie l
re
s
w
ch
I have lately sent from hens, will make it evident altogether,
at I have used no slacknes in writing unto you. For where
e 20
of this p
nt
my l
re
onely of
e 4 was delivered to your L. it may please
you to consider,
at I went immediately upon it towardes
e campe, and
being come as farre as
Swol
e 10 of this p
nt
, I receaved there the
l
re
s, w
ch
her Hig
nes
writte about the c
o
panies: w
ch
I imparted
e 11
to
e
Councel of estate
: the 12 I returned towardes
e Hage: the 14
I delivered my l
re
s to
e
States
: and I have signified their answear,
w
t
other
tinent maters, by my l
re
s of
e 15 16 19 and 25 of this
moneth, w
ch
I hope before this will be all w
t
your L. And yet I
see there is some cause to doubt
e diligence of
e Post, to whome
my l
re
s to your L. are c
o
monly c
o
signed. For his serv
a
ts tell me
plainely and give i t out very often in their speeches abroad, that
their Maister hath no benefit by
e cariage of suche l
re
s, as I doe
writte unto your L. Whereby they seeme to be unwilling to c
o
tinue
suche a course, as is burdensome unto them, and give me good occasion
to doubt in some sort their speedy [c
o
viance]. I should mervel at
that w
ch
was written from
Flushing,
of a practise of
Mondragon
for surprising
Breda,
and
at
that in like m
a
ner for
e taking of
Verdugo
, but
at I finde by
e l
re
s of
e English gentlem
e
of Flushing,
and likewise by their c
o
ference, when they come to this place,
at they
are muche misinformed of
e actions and affaires
at passe in these
quarters. For heere was never no suche report, nor any bruite
to
at purpose: as it were not almost possible,
at any occurence of
suche consequence should be kept from my knowledge: nor I would
not be so careles, as not to write it w
t
e soonest. Certaine
hazarders of
Berghen
have mette a post of
e Enemey, w
ch
was going
towardes
Brussels,
and intercepted his l
re
s, w
ch
e
Governor
s
e
t to me,
to be further c
o
veied to
e Councel and
Count Maurice
. I have
opened them all to
e number of 30 being written for
e most from
e Spa, and from
e townes about
Grolle
, by those
at of late have passed
e Rhine, their l
re
s bearing date
e 29 30 31 of this moneth, after
their account. There is nothing to be gathered by their l
re
s
from
e Spa, but that
e
Duke of Parma
is in good disposition, and
as they doo c
o
jecture, about
e first of September will returne into
fol.258v
France
. The rest of
e l
re
s from
e townes about Grolle, doo g
[reatly]
discourse
e weaknes of their forces through w
a
t of mony and munition,
vituals, good c
o
manders of their troupes, with other necessaries,
for w
ch
they growe in disorder, and diminish every day, w
t
sundrie
particularities w
ch
are fitte for Count Maurice to knowe out of hand:
for w
ch
I have imparted
e l
re
s to
e States, and sent them p
nt
ly to the
Campe. As touching
at Levie of 2000 men w
ch
was promised
long since, to be made in
Juliers,
e time appointed was
e first of
August after this c
o
trey stile,
e partie
at undertooke it was one
Stolbergh
a Coronel. He
p
tendeth by his l
re
s to be almost in a
readines: but as farres as can be learned by intelligence of others,
they are nothing nighe
e number: and those
at he hath raised are
unarmed altogether. Whereby the Enemy lieng between us and them
they shall hardely be able to joine w
t
Count Maurice. Howbeit
Count Hollocke
w
t
two cornets of horse, and 3 or 4 enseignes of foote,
is gone to
Sherembergh,
w
ch
is a towne of
e States upon
e borders
of
Zutphan
, about 2 miles distance from
Disbourgh,
and situat
thence southwest upon a gutte of
e Rhine. There
e Count will
expect
e Companies of Juliers, and if he be not hindred by a greater
force of
e Enemy, c
o
voy them to the campe, and then furnishe
them after w
t
necessarie armour. I will send your L.
c
o
mendations to my yong
L. of Bedford
, who is at
Leiden
at this p
nt
.
Albeit I am bound for many privat respectes, to doe his L. any
service,
at my qualitie will affourde, yet I trust he doth
ceave
at your l
re
unto me, w
ch
I receaved of himself, was a speciall
obligation.
And so I take my humble leave. From
e Hage
July 29 1592.
